textSection.textSectionContent: A number sign (#) is used with this entry because of evidence that intestinal carcinoid tumors are caused by heterozygous mutation in the SDHD gene ({602690}) on chromosome 11q23.

{1:Anderson (1966)} observed appendiceal carcinoid in father and daughter. {3:Eschbach and Rinaldo (1962)} reported fatal malignant carcinoid of the ileum in brother and sister. Duodenal carcinoid occurs with multiple endocrine neoplasia ({131100}, {162300}, {171400}).

{4:Karanjawala et al. (2000)} reported the first account of an individual with apparently nonmosaic complete maternal isodisomy of chromosome 8. The individual was identified during routine genotyping in a genomewide search for type II diabetes susceptibility genes, although he did not have diabetes. At age 26 years, the patient underwent surgical removal of an invasive ileal carcinoid tumor located about 1.5 m from the ileocecal junction. Metastases were noted in 4 regional lymph nodes. The patient had not had symptoms of carcinoid syndrome (cutaneous flushing, diarrhea, bronchial constriction) and the pre- and postoperative serotonin levels remained normal for 4 years.

{5:Kytola et al. (2002)} found heterozygous sequence variants of the SDHD gene in 2 of 18 midgut carcinoids and in 2 of 7 Merkel cell carcinomas analyzed (see {602690.0011} and {602690.0019}). The mutations in the patients with midgut carcinoids were germline; no normal DNA was available for any of the Merkel cell carcinoma patients to determine whether the mutations were present in the germline.

oldFormat.Oncology: Intestinal carcinoid {UMLS:C4024988} {HPO HP:0006723}; Appendiceal carcinoid; Malignant carcinoid of ileum;
